The Secretary of Commerce will assess US manufacturing to determine production, competitiveness, and necessary policies. A national manufacturing strategy will be developed to increase manufacturing jobs in the US. The Secretary of Commerce will submit a strategy to Congress within 180 days to strengthen US manufacturing competitiveness and identify emerging technologies. Targets for growth of the US manufacturing sector, including job creation, will be established for fiscal years 2012 through 2016. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on job creation targets for fiscal years 2012-2016. Additionally, a survey of Federal agencies supporting US manufacturers will be conducted within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will conduct a survey of Federal agencies supporting US manufacturers and submit a report to Congress with recommendations on how each agency can best support the national manufacturing strategy. The Secretary of Commerce will cooperate with Federal agencies to conduct a survey on US manufacturing sectors and gather necessary information. Additionally, the Secretary will hold listening sessions with key manufacturing witnesses. A report on the progress and trends in US manufacturing will be submitted to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a biennial survey of US manufacturers with facilities overseas to identify products and jobs. This is part of ongoing efforts to promote development and competitiveness in American manufacturing. The Secretary of Commerce conducts biennial surveys of US manufacturers with overseas facilities to identify products and jobs, aiming to promote development and competitiveness in the manufacturing sector. The information gathered is used to tailor policies for this purpose, and a database is maintained for collected data. A report on survey findings is submitted to Congress within 90 days of each survey. The Secretary of Commerce conducts biennial surveys of US manufacturers with overseas facilities to identify products and jobs, aiming to promote development and competitiveness in the manufacturing sector. The findings of the Secretary include longitudinal trends in US manufacturing and the creation of manufacturing jobs in the United States.
